episode_title: AI SERIES: 4 - How Fear and Regulation Impact AI in Finance with David Kaylor
transcript:
ï»¿Nikolas Hulewsky (00:00.841)
I hope. All right, David, super stoked to have you. I'm really excited to learn about some of the AI stuff that you're working on, where you are. Really quickly, will you give the people a brief background, who you are, where you work, what your role is?


David (00:16.482)
Yeah, for sure. So David Kaler, work at Alchemy Technology. We do banking services, digital banking services for credit unions, banks, across a variety of use cases, from like the app you log into, to digital account opening, to loan origination, all sorts of stuff.


My specific role is really around implementations of those platforms and services, essentially plugging our wires into banks' making sure all of that works. Lots of fun. Yeah.


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:52.651)
Yeah, you were saying that most credit unions or regional banks probably haven't built their own platform. They're using you or one of four of your competitors. Is that right? I wonder, what's it been like over the last, let's say three years, two years. Two years ago is when OpenAI had their moment. I was like, wow, chat GPT, I can ask it questions, my gosh. And like over that period of time, they've been...


David (01:02.272)
Mm-hmm. Yeah.


David (01:08.334)
you

companies have sort of shifted. All of sudden you're seeing roles like, he leads our AI implementation team and et cetera. David (01:40.002)
I would say there's a lot of talk. We have like a, yeah, yeah, yeah. I would say the doing is a little, not a fast follower, it's a slow follower. We're getting there. Honestly, I think we're doing okay internally. But I would say the industry as a whole, there's a lot of excitement and we have a data product that does use some AI models.

Okay, but not a lot of doing.

that we'd send out to our clients and stuff. And that's really well done. But I would say as a whole in the industry, I would say there's more excitement than actual productivity. Where we do have some productivity, yeah, go ahead.

Do you think that's because of the regulatory environment within banking?

There's a lot of fear, yeah. There's a lot of fear and apprehension. I would say in the banking sector, if you don't know if you're allowed to do something, people just assume you're not allowed to do it, which I would say is very different than most of the business world. If it's not, in the business world, if it's not explicitly denied, then you assume you can go forward. And I would say in the banking regulatory environment, it's quite the opposite. Yeah.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:50.593)
healthcare is very similar, right? It's like, hey, we don't move fast and break things in healthcare. We take our time. Same with banking, right? So tell me how you are currently using AI, both personally and within the organization.

Sure, so I've tinkered with a bunch of different things. I like trying the different models for different things. I'm somewhat technical in my background, but I'm by no means a developer or a server engineer to spin all that stuff up. So it actually spins up the servers, the database,


it hosts it all, know, serverless, native in the background, whatever. Basically, you don't have to know any of that or think about it. And so I built a little mini game on Replet that is essentially like, it's a click-based monster destroyer. I can bring that up if we want to look at that. It's kind of fun. It's a time waster. You know, it goes on for forever. Absolutely. Yep.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:58.549)
Yeah, I'd love to see it. This is more of a like entertainment, personal use, right? Okay. While you're pulling that up, I like to ask people this question. What, let me find it so can ask it appropriately.

Okay, what models are you using and what are you using them for currently?

Good question. I really like...


Gemini, the Google one, which I know gets a lot of hate.

And so Gemini is pretty good at that. I had a crappy little Python script that I was running manually every day in the morning on my laptop that would connect to some Jira APIs and send an email. And I popped it into Gemini and I said, hey, I want you to take this Python script.

you

and output me a Google Apps Script that can then be scheduled and automated. And it did it. First try, no errors, it just worked. I was blown away.

That's awesome. That's funny. I haven't heard people talk about Gemini, but that makes sense from that specific use case, right? It does its ecosystem really well.

Yeah.

Nikolas Hulewsky (10:41.847)
Hahaha

You

for various reasons. But everyone hates time tracking. No one's very good at remembering, doing it, real time. And so I had built a little Python script that would do it. We talked about that earlier. What it does now, it's this Google Apps script that I had Gemini rewrite from the Python into.


And it essentially makes an API call out to Jira and it says, hey, what tickets did so-and-so comment on today? Or yesterday, actually.


And then it gets that list and then it says hey what what gyr tickets did they log time to and then it does a diff against those two lists So we commented on ABC, but we only logged time to a and B And so the remainder is C was a ticket that had work done, but no time logged to it And so then it sends an email to that person and says hey you did work on this ticket But you forgot to like track your time to it

So what you're saying is it will go in and take one time point and subtract it from another and be able to match what they self-reported versus what they actually recorded in the system.


David (12:15.958)
Yeah, essentially.


David (12:22.604)

Okay.
